 1. OVERVIEW A. BACKGROUND 1.1 Eritrea is located in the northeastern part of Africa. The overall size of the country is about 125,000 square km, with a coast line of 1,000 km, and a population estimated in the range of 3.0 and 3.5 million, including nearly half a million refugees in Sudan. Eritrea is one of the poorest countries in the world, with a GDP per capita in the range of US$ 160 to US$ 190 (less than half of the average per capita income of sub- Saharan countries). While there are no firm estimates of the incidence of poverty, it is believed that about two thirds of the population is poor (more than 50% calculating the impact of food aid). The country's social indicators are consistent with its low per capita income. Life expectancy at birth is estimated to be low at about 46 years, compared to 50 years for Sub-Saharan Africa. Infant mortality is 135 per thousand live births, the under- five child mortality rate is 203 per thousand live births, and maternal mortality is over 700 per one hundred thousand live births. Also in the education sector the indicators are lower than in most African countries. The illiteracy rate stands at 80% for men and 90% for women, and the gross enrollment rate at the primary level is among the lowest in Africa (47% in 1994). 1.2 Historically, Eritrea was a nation of skilled people with a wealth of experience in entrepreneurship, commerce, and international trade. At the time of its liberation, in 1991, Eritrea inherited a devastated economy: enterprises were not operational; the agricultural sector was severely damaged by the war; major infrastructure was damaged or destroyed; and basic social service facilities had suffered from war damage or serious neglect. The disruption of family life due to war, displacement and drought, has left thousands of children as destitutes and orphans. It is estimated that there are nearly 100,000 internally displaced people, and some 50,000 ex-fighters have been demobilized for reintegration into civilian life. 1.3 Enormous pressures have been placed on Eritrea's forest and land resources. It has been estimated that around one hundred years ago, as much as 30 percent of the country may have been under closed forests and woodland types. Currently, agricultural land clearance continues to place the heaviest pressures on forested areas, and this has been exacerbated by customary notions of land and resource tenure which limited the incentive to cultivate and manage trees. Though no recent inventories have been carried out, the FAO estimated, in 1994 that total forest and woodland cover accounts for around 12 percent of the land area. 1.4 With liberation, Eritrea is returning to its traditions of resourcefulness, shared endeavor, and entrepreneurship. Despite its shattered economy, the country has rapidly re-established the main functions of government, and embarked on an impressive process of reconstruction. The country has many strengths which support this process: a strong sense of nationhood strengthened through the liberation struggle, and a well-organized and active community structure; strong ownership of national development programs; and a flexible approach to economic development. Both the reconstruction efforts and
 2 the more recent development strategies and programs demonstrate a blend of orientations: building solutions that respond to and take advantage of the special characteristics of the country; clear public leadership imbued with a strong commitment to social justice; openness to and encouragement of private sector initiative, both domestic and foreign; utilization of the talents and resources of Eritrea's well educated and successful diaspora; and outreach to visions, methods, and technologies beyond the African context. The sections below summarize the most significant results achieved in the four years after liberation. B. RECENT ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE 1.5 Since liberation, Eritrea has laid policy foundations for a liberal market economy operating alongside a unitary governmental structure that reaches down to and represents the interests of the lowest community levels. In a relatively short period the country has made significant progress in restructuring key institutions, establishing governmental functions in all key sectors, and eliminating a number of restrictive policies inherited from the past. In May 1991, the Government of Eritrea launched a Recovery and Rehabilitation Program, aimed at jump-starting the economy. However the economy improved strongly in 1994 and it is estimated to have grown by 14.1 percent in real terms. Industrial production, as well as service sector activities have continued to expand due to an increase in exports, a growing private small-scale sector, the partial rehabilitation of a few larger enterprises, a strong resurgence of construction activities, and recent good harvests. 1.6 Policy Reforms. The Government has introduced a number of important policy reforms aimed at stimulating investment and economic growth, and reducing protectionism and controls. Trade policies have been revised and simplified import licensing procedures introduced. Export taxes have been eliminated. A new Investment Law has been prepared to replace the 1991 Investment Code, opening all sectors to private investments. The former Labor Code, which prohibited hiring of labor by the private sector is being revised and private hiring of labor being permitted. Centralized marketing and planning systems have been disbanded so that most public and private enterprises are free of price and marketing restrictions. A land proclamation has been issued, providing every farmer with life-time usufruct rights, giving women equal access to land, making provision for usufructs to remain within the family on the death of the land-holder; permitting rental and mortgaging of land-use rights; permitting the sale of capital improvements; and reconfirming the right to enter into share-cropping arrangements. 1.7 Institutional Strengthening Under a comprehensive public sector strengthening program, the Government has implemented a large number of measures to rationalize institutions and has completed the process of streamlining of the civil service, comprising about 15,000 employees. Efforts are also being made to address the shortage of skilled staff in key positions, and the mandate of the University of Asmara has been focused to support the effort to build local capacity in key technical and managerial areas.
 3 C. RECENT SOCIAL PERFORMANCE 1.8 Health Status. For the large majority of Eritreans, available health status indicators suggest low life expectancy and high infant, child and maternal mortality. Besides the high average levels of these rates, there is substantial variation among the regions. The main health problems are primarily ones which are amenable to PHC interventions. According to a recently conducted Burden of Diseases study (BOD, 1994), the top five diseases in terms of discounted years lost are perinatal/maternal; diarrhea; acute respiratory infections; tuberculosis; and malaria, accounting for over 62 percent of the BOD in Eritrea. While this pattern of disease has lead to low life expectancy to date, it also means that with steady increase in PHC service coverage this burden of disease can be transformed rather quickly. Finally, since food supplies depend on good rains and related harvests, the nutritional status of the population can exacerbate much of the key health problems, including the BOD. 1.9 The State of Health Care Delivery. Since independence the Government has been expanding the provision of PHC with the objective of reducing deaths from easily controllable diseases and enhancing awareness of good health practices to improve the productivity of the work force. The health expenditures as a percent of total Government expenditures show a consistent incremental trend after independence, with a consequent improvement in the extension of primary health services. The MOH estimates 46 percent of the population have access to basic health services. Though this estimate is based on approximate information, nevertheless it is undoubtful that the share of population with access to PHC services is constantly increasing. Data gathered during a recent Initial Health Sector Review (1995), show a significant increase in the number of children from 0-5 years of age whose weight and height were monitored at health facilities from 1993 to 1994. The share increased from about 6.9% in 1993, to over 22.4% in 1994. The same review also recorded nearly a doubling of the share of pregnant women having at least one ante-natal visit from 1993 (14.5%) to 1994 (28.2%). The share of births delivered at a health facility increased from about 2.7% (1993) to 9% (1994). From 1991 to 1994 a total of 181 health facilities at various level have been constructed or rehabilitated, facilitating the provision of PHC in the rural and most remote areas of the country. Regarding the immunization coverage, information for 1993 and 1994 is not available in comparable form at this time to compare improvements that are undoubtedly occurring, but there is evidence that the number of facilities providing imnmunization have increased and the solar power storage refrigerators for vaccine have been installed in many facilities during 1994. Finally, increase has been registered in the use of contraceptive (from 1.7% in 1993 to 2.3% of women between the age of 15 and 45 years in 1994), even if the contraceptive prevalence is still very low in the country. 1.10 Education Status. Since 1991, the Government policy had the main objective of increasing access, improving the quality, and guaranteeing equity in the distribution of primary education services. The budget for the education sector increased almost threefold and the results have been impressive. When compared to the 1992/93 academic year enrollment in pre-school, primary, middle and secondary education increased by almost 10, 12, 15 and 4% respectively (reaching 47.4% in 1993/94 at the primary level;
 4 22.4% at the junior secondary level; and 13.7% at the senior secondary level). In more than 25 centers literacy programs were provided to 4,000 adults, while the evening programs enrolled more than 12,500 adults. The government identified two major constraints in primary education: lack of infrastructure, and shortage of teachers. Between 1992 and 1994, 80 primary schools were constructed and 52 rehabilitated, mostly with direct involvement of local communities. In 1990/91 there were 4,500 teachers in Eritrea. About half of these were Ethiopians, and following liberation they went back to their homeland, which resulted in severe teacher shortages. In 1993/94 the number had risen to 7,265. As a result of this intensive training campaign, the average pupil teacher ratios fell between 1991/92 and 1993/94 from 41 to 39 at the primary level; 37 to 34 at the lower secondary level; and 38 to 32 at the senior secondary level. 2. POLICY FRAMEWORK AND LESSONS LEARNED A. DEVELOPMENT AND SECTOR STRATEGIES FOR ERITREA 2.1 Eritrea's Development Strategy. The national development objective is to create a modem, technologically advanced and internationally competitive economy in the context of a free, democratic and decentralized political system, where private enterprise is the driving economic force. To achieve these objectives the Government has adopted a broad-based growth strategy that has aspects of rehabilitation, reconstruction and development covering all sectors of the economy. Major components of this strategy are human capital formation, with education and health as key inputs, export-oriented development both in industry and agriculture, infrastructural development to remove critical bottlenecks, environmental restoration and protection, and the promotion of the private sector. 2.2 The center-piece of this strategy is the establishment of an efficient, outward looking private sector-led market economy, with the Government playing a proactive role to stimulate private economic activities. The economic role of the public sector would normally be restricted to those areas which the private sector may tend to avoid because of the externalities. 2.3 Sector Policies and Development Programs. In the context of the overall development policy framework, sectoral strategies and programs have been prepared. They provide the basis for public and/or private sector programs and activities to address the various social problems of the country and to realize its development potential. 2.4 Basic Education. The Government is developing a national policy for the education sector, which builds upon and develops the initiatives taken by the EPLF during the period of the struggle. The policy aims to: (i) promote basic education in a way that takes into account the specific characteristics and conditions of each region; (ii) establish a seven-year basic education system; (iii) promote the use of local languages as a medium of instruction at the primary level; (iv) progressively eradicate illiteracy; (v) develop curricula for secondary education responsive to the needs and opportunities of
 S labor market; (vi) promote the use of English as a medium of instruction at the secondary level; (vii) promote and improve the quality of technical and vocational education and training; (viii) encourage and promote female education; (ix) provide special education services for the disabled; (x) guarantee a balanced mix of centralized and decentralized education management structures; (xi) facilitate the opening of private schools at all levels; and (xii) encourage communities to play a stronger role in the management of education services. 2.5 The Ministry of Education (MOE) has drafted a five year development plan for the education sector. The strategies focus on improvement of the quality of the education services through development of new and more updated curricula; improved access to educational services through the construction of new schools especially at the basic level; recruitment and training of new teachers; retraining of teachers already in-service; a policy of cost-recovery through the direct involvement of communities and parents in the provision, management, and financing of the education services; and, the reduction of gender imbalances through the implementation of intensive campaigns to promote girls' education. Other cornerstones of the MOE strategy are the emphasis on adult literacy and post-literacy programs, particularly for women; the development of a variety of approaches to technical and vocational training; improved incentives for teachers and education personnel, in the framework of a wider restructuring of the civil service; and, capacity building for all levels of the education sector. 2.6 The most urgent short-term priorities focus on basic education, non-formal education, and technical and vocational training. This will involve the construction or rehabilitation of 350 equipped elementary schools in the next five years, in order to provide each village or territory (an area serving nomadic or scattered population) with a school, with particular attention given to the previously neglected areas of the country. In addition this will require the training or retraining of a sufficient number of teachers to operate the newly constructed or rehabilitated facilities; the implementation of a nationwide awareness campaign to improve girls' attendance and performance in basic education; the improvement of teacher training; and, the preparation of new curricula based on the history. traditions, and socio-economic situation of the country, sensitive to regional, ethnic, and linguistic differences. 2.7 Basic Health. Since independence, the Government has been developing and implementing a health sector policy designed to: (i) reduce the burden of disease; and (ii) educate the public to engage in good health practice leading to improved productivity. The strategies to achieve these objectives are: (i) making available to the public basic health services, and especially primary health care (PHC); (ii) containing and controlling the spread of major health hazards; (iii) enabling the private sector to participate in the delivery of health services within the regulatory framework of the Ministry of Health (MOH); (iv) promoting community and beneficiary participation in financing health care; (v) introducing National Health Insurance; and (vi) promoting the dissemination of information about good health practices. 2.8 MOH's draft Basic Health Strategic Implementation plan is currently being reviewed by the Government. The key priority is the strengthening of primary health care
 6 services, in line with the broad national goals of equity, service accessibility, affordability, community involvement (especially in financing), intersectoral collaboration, and decentralization of management. Emphasis will be given to the sustainability of health systems at all levels. To strengthen the quality and accessibility of primary health care, improvements in the development, organization, and management of health care infrastructure are vital. In addition, the plan aims to create an enabling environment to ensure an adequate supply of essential resources: human, financial and materials, such as drugs and equipment. Finally, the strategy promotes intersectoral collaboration, vital for primary health care goals, especially regarding nutrition, environmental sanitation, and clean water. 2.9 Rural Water Supply. Improved access to water for social and economic development is one of the top priorities of the Government. Access to safe drinking water supply in rural areas is a particular concern. Rural water supply coverage is estimated at 7%; and 48% of the population rely on hand dug wells which are often unsafe and unreliable (71% of all hand dug wells are less than 5 meters in depth). 2.10 As an input to the Government's Macroeconomic Policy, the Water Resources Department (WRD) within the Ministry of Energy, Mines, and Water Resources has drafted a policy that states the Government's intention to: (i) reduce its current role in the "provision" of water and focus on, or "promote" water resources management; (ii) encourage private sector participation in the sector, including privatizing drilling and other implementation functions; (iii) treat water as an economic good, requiring users to pay for what they consume; (iv) conserve water and reduce pollution; (v) take a balanced approach to the distribution of water among social and economic sectors; (vi) ensure the active participation of the population, particularly women, in water works; and (vii) facilitate the equitable distribution of water in all sectors. 2.11 The Government is planning a Rural Water Supply and Environmental Sanitation Program (ERIWESP) in consultation with key sector agencies, which will review Government policies, strategies, and plans; evaluate current programs and projects; carry out a water resources assessment; and develop a comprehensive framework for the sector. Key issues to be addressed include: community participation, gender, standardization, sustainability, health and hygiene education and coordination. The outputs from the formulation phase will help shape Government policy for the sector and lay the foundations for sector development. 2.12 In addition to the above, the Government is currently reviewing several policy decisions concerning community participation in sector development, and intends to hold a National Meeting on Operation and Maintenance of Water Supply and Sanitation to discuss and confirm these recommendations. It is intended that communities bear the full recurrent costs (operation and maintaining) of their schemes. In addition it is proposed that they establish user charges that allow them to meet the replacement cost of pumping technology. In the long term they are expected to be responsible for the full replacement costs of their schemes. These criteria (recurrent and replacement costs) will help to guide the selection of technology that is appropriate both in terms of per capita costs and sustainability.
 7 2.13 Soil, Water and Forestry Conservation. The Government accords a high priority to the preservation of the environment, as long-term growth depends on the sustainable use of the country's natural resources and assets. Based on an extensive process of consultation with community organizations and all major ministries, the Government recently produced a National Environmental Management Plan for Eritrea (NEMP-E), which was officially adopted in 1995. In accordance with a recommendation of the NEMP-E, work on drafting of an environmental law has begun in May 1995, and is expected to be completed in a few months. The Eritrean Agency for the Environment (EAE) has been established as an interim secretariat within the Ministry of Local Government, but with a large degree of autonomy. 2.14 The main objective of the NEMP-E is to provide a framework for coordinating the protection and enhancement of Eritrea's natural resource base. It identifies a wide range of actions for improvements in environmental health, management of human settlements, the sustainable development and preservation of the coastal and marine environment, containment of industrial pollution, improved water management, curtailment of land degradation and deforestation, and the preservation of bio-diversity. The NEMP-E highlights two important themes underlying the government's overall approach to environmental management. The first is that the environment should be treated not as a separate issue, but as an integral component of all sectors. Consequently NEMP-E's main emphasis is on building up the skills and awareness of staff in the line ministries, and on the capacity of ministries to oversee the implementation of environmental assessments for projects within their areas of responsibility. A second theme underlying the NEMP-E, is the importance of community participation in all aspect of environmental management. Many of the suggested measures are based on collaborative efforts by communities and government, and on a continuing dialogue that respects the traditional knowledge of communities and raises public awareness of the implications of various forms of human activities on the environment. 2.15 Another important instrument of the environmental policy is the land policy, included in the Government's Macro-Policy document. It states that the objectives of the new land policy are to establish a revised tenure system that: (i) encourages long-term investments in agriculture and prudent environmental management; (ii) assures women's rights to land on equal basis with men; and, (iii) promotes commercial agriculture. 2.16 Presently, conservation programs are carried out with an emphasis on structural measures: terracing, bunding, contour ditches, and check dams have all been used to reduce run-off, enhance water infiltration, and retain soil particles. In physical terms, the achievements have been impressive, but maintenance remains dependent on additional injections of food or cash for work. Afforestation is another major component of the conservation efforts. While millions of seedlings have been planted under communal responsibility, much of the plantations have died because of lack of maintenance. To the extent that soil and nutrients are retained on cropland through conservation measures, there will be a relative improvement in productivity, which however must be weighted against the loss of agricultural land, taken up by the structure. The net result is not always positive. In terms of hydrogeological benefits, catchment conservation will probably produce mixed results. Because Eritrea has low rainfall and high evapo-
 8 transpiration, terracing may substantially reduce the run-off available for conservation in reservoirs. On the other hand, it is believed to increase infiltration into the groundwater aquifers where they exist. Terracing also reduces the amount of sediment transport and particularly the coarse sediment which forms a bed load in watercourses. 2.17 Feeder Roads. The state of disrepair of roads and other infrastructure in Eritrea has resulted largely from damage during the protracted war and the consequent neglect of maintenance. The Government has, since independence, embarked on a program to rehabilitate essential roads and bridges, and maintain its road network. The Government's Macro-Policy is to develop trunk roads for domestic and regional services and the comprehensive domestic network in stages. Efforts will also be made to strengthen the institutional structures and establish the operational framework for the continued maintenance of the improved network. In line with the overall process of decentralization, the national administrative structure for the sector has been revised. Rural roads will be improved and maintained through a partnership involving the provincial Administrations, Districts, and local communities through their various councils (Baitos), with some support from the Center. 2.18 The road network comprises three main classes of roads: Primary or Trunk, Secondary, and Feeder roads (as well as community access road). A framework agreement has been signed between the Ministry of Construction (MOC) and the Ministry of Local Government (MOLG) which, inter alia, delineates responsibilities for the various classes of roads. Under the new agreement, the responsibility for the management and maintenance of feeder roads, as well as the maintenance only of secondary roads will be assigned to the Regional Administrations. Technical design standards will be established and approved by the Roads Department of the MOC. The MOLG will coordinate the activities of the various regions and will not assume direct responsibility for feeder roadworks. Community councils will organize the maintenance of feeder roads with technical support from the Regional Administration. 2.19 Micro-finance. The Government's development strategy aims at a growth in individual, family, and community economic self-reliance to free the country from dependency on relief assistance and subsidies. The key to this goal is to promote employment. In part, this will be accomplished by the expansion of the formal private sector. However, this will need to be accompanied by a parallel development of the informal sector, both urban and in the area of rural non-farming activities; and by a strengthening of subsistence and surplus yielding traditional cultivation and pastoralism. 2.20 Broadening access to financial services is an essential step towards encouraging individual and group initiative and thus reducing people's dependence on subsidized public programs. Eritrea inherited from the previous regime a poorly diversified, narrow, largely urban-based, government-owned financial sector. Lack of competition in the system has contributed to low efficiency and poor services, adding to the lack of outreach and lack of flexibility of formal financial institutions. It is now a Government's priority to develop and diversify the financial sector, and, as part of this process, to encourage the growth of micro-finance institutions, particularly in rural areas. While Government may act as a catalyst in this endeavor, the aim is to rely on private group or community
 9 initiatives. Eritrea's well established community structure (which have been accorded a legal identity) and their familiarity with handling financial transactions, provides a basis for the development of local micro-credit and savings groups. Improved access to credit is an essential plank in the Government's efforts to promote the social and economic status of women, and to facilitate the reintegration of displaced people and former combatants. The improved provision of micro-credit will be accompanied by a vigorous prograrn of technical training implemented in collaboration with the private sector. 2.21 In addition to improving access to financial services by both rural and urban dwellers, the Government will support the growth of small, already established business operating in areas beyond the outreach of formal financial institutions. These business can make a strong contribution to employment creation and income generation throughout the country, hence the need to ensure their access to credit and other services they may require. B. WORLD BANK COUNTRY ASSISTANCE STRATEGY FOR ERITREA 2.22 The Government's overall development strategy is accelerated and sustainable broad-based economic growth, human resources development, and well targeted social programs, all aimed at improving the living standards and reducing poverty. In line with this policy, the Bank's program of assistance over the next three years will focus on supporting the country's efforts towards rehabilitation and recovery, investment in infrastructure and priority productive sectors, and the development of human resources, all with the over-riding goal of reducing poverty. Since a large proportion of Eritrea's population continues to suffer from lack of basic social services and doesn't have the educational skills and access to capital that will enable it to fully participate in and benefit from the recovery and growth process, the Bank's strategy aims to enhance the access to and quality of basic social services for the poor and to support well targeted community- based programs that will address the needs of the most vulnerable people in the society. 2.23 The Bank's strategy emphasizes: (i) supporting the participation of communities in the development process, including the provision, management, and maintenance of basic social services, and building community managerial and implementation capacity; (ii) strengthening the role of local communities and other private sector institutions in the financing of social services; (iii) the importance of improving cost-efficiency, and the development of a national policy aiming at maximizing cost-recovery in the provision of services; and (iv) a focus on women, including improving the participation of girls in primary education, maternal health care, family planning services, increased literacy among women, the use of labor-saving methods, and improving women' s income-earning opportunities. The ECDF project will be an important contribution to achieving these objectives by providing essential basic assets and services to poor communities, improving the health and education status of large portions of the population, and providing target groups, particularly women, with opportunities to increase incomes, reduce vulnerability, and strengthen self-reliance.
 10 C. LESSONS FROM OTHER SOCIAL FUNDS 2.24 Main Characteristics of Social Funds. The World Bank is financing social funds and social programs in Latin America, Africa, Asia, and more recently Eastern Europe, often with the support of other bilateral and multilateral donors. Although social funds vary in design, they share some common basic features, that made them particularly attractive to governments undertaking economic and political reforms aimed at poverty reduction and the strengthening of local self-reliance. These include simplicity, flexibility, low cost, and ability to generate visible benefits rapidly. Social funds are essentially demand-driven programs, which involve the active and substantial participation of the beneficiaries (usually community groups of one kind or another). These funds generally operate through autonomous or semi-autonomous financial and administrative structures, and use procedures for appraisal, procurement, and disbursement designed to be simple, flexible, and rapidly responsive to community demand, and which allow communities to participate in the management of the project cycle. Social funds finance small sub-projects to improve basic infrastructure and services, and it is customary for each category of sub-project to have funding ceilings to ensure that the resources are directed at essential community needs. 2.25 Social funds generally differ from public sector implemented programs in two important ways. Firstly, the social fund itself is not an implementing agency but relies on beneficiaries, local community organizations, intermediaries, and contracted specialists to implement projects. Secondly, social funds are often given certain levels of autonomy, such as the right to employ their own staff on special salary scales, a system of financial allocation and replenishment separate from the civil service budget, and their own set of operating rules and procedures that may differ from the requirements of sector ministries. Although some social funds have an organizational structure embedded within a government agency, it is almost always the case that this structure has a separate identity. Many social funds are established entirely outside the civil service as semi-autonomous public agencies, and in a few cases, they have a semi-private or NGO status. 2.26 Findings of Recent Analyses. Several analyses and research studies have been carried out on social funds, their strength, limitations, and conditions for success. These include three World Bank studies: a study by the Africa Technical Department on "Social Actions Programs and Social Funds, A Review of Design and Implementation in Sub- Sahara Africa" (1993); a discussion paper prepared by the Education and Social Policy Department on "Social Funds: Strengths, Weaknesses, and Conditions for Success" (1995); and a technical note prepared by The Africa Human Resources and Poverty Division entitled "Study of Procurement and Disbursement Issues in Projects with Community Participation" (1994). A common finding of these studies is that social funds are successful when they: (i) have support and commitment from highest political level to preserve the integrity of the fund, its objectives and mandate; (ii) are able to operate with sufficient autonomy to respond rapidly and directly to community demands, while at the same time having clear accountability and transparency of operation; (iii) promote the participation of beneficiary communities in sub-project identification and implementation to ensure that proposals are genuinely beneficiary-initiated; (iv) have a qualified, and
 11 committed motivated staff and a system of incentives based on merit; (v) have a rigorous management and MIS system and a streamlined organizational structure; (vi) have flexible financing mechanisms subject to a rigorous appraisal process; (vii) have an effective coordinating mechanism with line ministries; (viii) have an intensive and thorough process of supervision and audit; and, (ix) operate in an action-research mode to learn from experience through mechanisms such as beneficiary assessments, research on patterns of implementation, and exchange of views with sector and community experts. 2.27 Major Issues and Limitations. The following have been identified as the major issues, challenges, and limitations social funds may experience. They may face a trade- off between rapid implementation of quality projects, and building indigenous institutional and technical capacity. They have shown limited success in implementing credit programs, especially where the fund attempts to operate as a retailer of credit. Because they have limited resources, to be effective they must be an integral part of a larger program to reduce poverty. Finally, to generate genuine and reliable community demand for social fund support, they must be able to directly reach out to poor beneficiaries and communities, rather than rely on indirect methods of assessing local needs. 2.28 Major Strengths and Potential. Small infrastructure projects have generally been the most successful type of social fund initiative in terms of quality, sustainability, and beneficial impact, providing communities with assets that directly increase incomes and production. Small projects concerned with social assistance and income-generating are usually more complex and labor-intensive, and their success depends on the capacity of local support organizations. However, if designed in a way that maximizes their special potential, social funds can provide a parallel track to the conventional public- sector planning cycle, allowing a community with energy and commitment to launch initiatives within its own time-frame. Social funds are an effective way of encouraging private efforts which can often deliver more cost-effective results than the public sector can achieve alone. A number of social funds (including the ECRF pilot) have shown that community-initiated infrastructure projects can be implemented at a lower cost than equivalent publicly managed projects. The social fund mechanism can be an effective way of obtaining community investments, which reduces the cost to public funds and establishes a basis of ownership around which maintenance arrangements can be built. Finally, the experience of social fund participation can make a valuable contribution to community development, by helping to build managerial competencies, encouraging community decision-making on shared assets, and developing a sense of achievement and self-reliance. D. THE EXPERIENCE OF THE PILOT COMMUNITY REHABILITATION FUND 2.29 Main Characteristics of the Pilot Project. The Eritrean Community Rehabilitation Fund (ECRF) was launched as a pilot operation in April 1993, as part of the Recovery and Rehabilitation Program for Eritrea (RRPE) with financing from IDA (US$ 1 million), Italy (US$ 4.6 million), the Netherlands (US$ 0.78 million), and Australia (US$ 1 million). UNDP provided technical assistance and management support
 12 for project implementation. The Government's financial contribution was US$ 3 million equivalent, bringing the financial resources to a total of US$ 10.38 million. ECRF's main objective was to support the rehabilitation and construction of basic social and economic infrastructure (basic health facilities, primary schools, micro-dams, water schemes, flood control structures, feeder roads and bridges). The pilot ECRF was implemented in all 9 provinces of the country, with particular focus on the very remote areas and those most damaged by the effects of the war. More than 90% of sub-projects were implemented in rural areas. All phases of the ECRF project cycle have involved significant community participation, with communities contributing at least the mandatory 10% of project costs (but in many cases more). The pilot phase, which is due to close in February 1996, has provided the basis for testing the feasibility and viability of community-initiated development activities, and for determining whether this experience would justify a continuation and expansion of the ECRF. Based on the successful evaluation of the pilot, the Government has decided to continue and expand the operation of the ECRF as a fully- fledged program. The expansion (which the proposed project will support) is based closely on the structure and modalities of the pilot. Therefore the paragraphs below provide details of the most important features of the pilot operation. 2.30 Organization and Structure of the Pilot Fund. The ECRF pilot has been managed by an autonomous group within the Ministry of Local Government. The structure of this group consists of a Central Unit in Asmara, and nine Sub-Units located in the offices of the Local Government Provincial Administrations. The role of the Sub- Units is to screen and appraise sub-project proposals submitted by communities, and submit those that are judged as viable to the Central Unit. There the appraisals are reviewed, final financing decisions taken, contractual arrangements set up with the beneficiary communities, and the implementation program established. The Central Office has carried the major responsibility for procurement and disbursement, and for close liaison with sector ministries. The Sub-Units have carried responsibility for the community promotion and outreach and assisting communities to develop sub-project proposals, and for supervising and assisting the implementation process. The Central Unit has consisted of a General Manager, and 7 professionals, and each Sub-Unit had a Project Officer (usually a qualified engineer), and was managed by the Head of the Provincial Development and Reconstruction Office who is employed and paid under the local government structure. 2.31 The Project Cycle. The project cycle begins with outreach activities to explain to communities what type of project can be funded by ECRF and the terms of community participation/contribution. On receipt of community sub-project proposals, the Project Officer visits the site and appraises the project. The Local Government Provincial Administration checks that the proposed sub-project is in line with sectoral development policies and priorities, and that funds will be allocated by the provincial sector agency to cover recurrent expenditures. Line ministries provide standard designs or guidelines for project implementation. Appraised proposals are then sent to the Central Unit for review and final approval (or deferral or rejection). For those proposals approved, agreements with local community, giving particular attention to arrangements for maintenance and sustainability of the infrastructure to be built are signed.
 13 2.32 Projects are implemented by local contractors selected through a process of competitive bidding. Where there are no private contractors available, implementation has been carried by NGOs or Local Governments together with local communities. Community committees and the ECRF Project Officers supervise project implementation, monitoring quality control, and compliance with works schedule. The ECRF project cycle has typically lasted approximately 6 months: 2 months for preparation, and 4 months for implementation, although these periods vary by type of infrastructure and area. 2.33 Community Participation and Contribution. Eritrea has a long tradition of community participation and the investment of community resources in the provision of local infrastructure and services. This has been a special feature of community life where councils of elders (known as Baitos) are responsible for decisions concerning the collective welfare of the community. During the liberation struggle, the EPLF promoted the establishment of locally elected councils, and after independence these bodies (which kept the traditional name of Baitos) were formally allocated a wide range of powers and responsibilities. Village and district Baibos prioritize community needs for development support, and transmit their priorities to the Provincial Administration. During the Pilot, Committees of these Baitos have acted as the main liaison between the communities and the ECRF. 2.34 Communities have made a contribution of at least 10 percent to implementation costs of a sub-project either in cash, kind, labor, or in a blend of these, depending on the resources available within the community. It has been the goal of the ECRF to maximize the level of community contribution, while being sensitive to the limits of especially poor communities. Besides supervising contractors, community committees are responsible for storing the construction materials; and when it is specified in the project contract, communities contribute free labor (for example, carrying water, and unloading trucks) and some materials (generally, stones, gravel, and sand). It is also responsibility of the community committees to draw up schedules for the work of local people at the sites. When a number of communities have contributed to a project (for example, for feeder road rehabilitation), they have been responsible for managing coordination among themselves. 2.35 Achievements of the Pilot ECRF. The operational timetable of the pilot ECRF has been divided into three phases. During the first phase, ECRF implemented projects mainly in basic health and education - rehabilitation and construction of elementary schools, health centers, and health stations. In phases two and three, ECRF broadened its portfolio, including sub-projects supporting small-scale irrigation, water supply, and feeder roads. In February 1995, the ECRF had implemented 75 sub-projects, consisting of 34 elementary schools, 17 health stations, 9 health centers, 3 bridge reconstructions, I flood control program, I feeder road, and 8 water supply projects. In addition, using Government funds, the ECRF reconstructed I senior secondary school , and I regional hospital. At the same date, ECRF had received and appraised more than 250 proposals. The third phase, presently under implementation, has a pipeline of about 80 projects, mostly in basic social sectors, water supply, and small-scale irrigation. It is expected that by the end of the pilot phase ECRF will have implemented more than 150 sub-projects.

ORIGINS OF THE PROJECT 3.1 The Eritrea Community Rehabilitation Fund (ECRF) was established as a pilot (within the Recovery and Rehabilitation Program for Eritrea) to test a community-based mechanism aimed at improving the economic and social conditions of the rural poor especially in very remote and devastated areas of the country. The pilot phase was intended to pave the way for a future expanded community-based program. The evaluation and mid-term review demonstrated that the pilot ECRF accomplished its objectives, and the Government concluded that its satisfactory performance justifies the expansion of the fund's activities in terns of both volume of project investments and sectors covered. In October 1994, the ECRF management team started the preparatory activities for the expanded phase, and in January 1995, the Government requested Bank assistance. The follow-up program will be implemented under the name "Eritrea Community Development Fund" (ECDF), to emphasize that the fund will focus on sustainable development interventions, shifting from the emphasis on recovery and rehabilitation of the pilot phase. B. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.2 The Project's objectives are to finance community-based sub-projects which will: (i) support the rehabilitation and development of basic social and economic infrastructure critical to the improvement and development of the economic and social conditions of the population, especially in the remote and war devastated areas of Eritrea; and (ii) improve the income-generating capacity of poor people and households. These will include: (i) social sector projects, including the rehabilitation and construction of basic social infrastructure and provision of social services using labor-intensive techniques and community participation (construction or rehabilitation of primary schools, junior secondary schools, health stations, health centers and clinics; water pumps and other water supply sources; sanitation and the supply of basic equipment; as well as the provision of basic social services); (ii) activities that will be beneficial to environment conservation and rehabilitation in areas severely affected by soil erosion, excessive run- off and high levels of deforestation (including check dams and hillside terraces, tree planting and other related activities that have a positive impact on the environment); (iii) implementation of pilot micro savings and credit schemes; (iv) economic resources management projects which will be simple in design and implemented using labor- intensive techniques (including reconstruction and extensive rehabilitation of feeder roads, market storage facilities and other similar infrastructure); and. (v) capacity building to increase the ability of communities to identify development priorities, manage project implementation, and maintain assets (including those built with the ECDF support), and to strengthen regional and local government institutions.
 16 3.3 The project supports several imperatives in the need of improving the socio- economic environment, particularly the Government's Macro-Policy which establishes the framework for Eritrea's development. The ECDF will make an important contribution to the Government's human resource development priority, by assisting communities to construct or rehabilitate basic social infrastructure, and improve the quality of basic social services. It will also respond to the need of reducing poverty and dependency on relief assistance by providing poor members of local communities, that cannot survive on traditional agricultural activities, with alternative income-generation options. Finally, the ECDF is a representative model of the thrust of the Government's development strategy, which emphasizes decentralized responsibility; community self-help; private initiative and cost-sharing; the redress of the inequalities among regions, and social groups, especially women; and, care for the environment and local responsibility for conservation. C. PROJECT DESCRIPTION 3.4 The ECDF will be a demand-driven program. It will finance sub-projects that have been identified and requested by local communities, and in whose design, implementation, monitoring, maintenance and sustainability local communities will play a key role. On an exceptional basis, ECDF in collaboration with regional and local government institutions will also assist local communities which do not have strong organizational capacity in assessing their priorities, promote sub-projects' proposals and implement them. Sub-projects will be appraised to ensure that: (i) they are developmental rather than relief in nature; (ii) they are sustainable, because the assets created with ECDF support will be well maintained and recurrent costs covered by the relevant line Ministry in partnership with local communities; (iii) they respond to priorities of poor communities; (iv) the investment is justified in terms of economic, and social returns; (v) they support the Government's environmental conservation and rehabilitation objectives; and (vi) they are consistent with the Government's sector development strategies. For each sub-project it is mandatory that the benefiting community form a Community Project Committee, which will be party to contractual arrangements with the ECDF. The ECDF will operate a capacity building program of promotion, education and training to assist communities to participate actively in the sub- project cycle. 3.5 The ECDF does not implement projects, but supports and facilitates the efforts of local communities, and ensures the provision of technical expertise in project implementation and management wherever the community needs. The implementation of the rehabilitation works will be carried out in a decentralized, pragmatic and flexible way, and will give a large responsibility to the community for preparation and supervision. 1. Following the promotion phase, communities may develop and submit proposals for Fund support through their representatives to the ECDF Regional Branch. A "community" can be a village, a group of villages, a district area, a cluster of communities in the case of infrastructure covering more than one community (such as feeder road rehabilitation), a neighborhood in urban areas, or (in the case of micro-credit), a group of individuals collaborating in a business venture. Communities will be represented by properly constituted Community Project Committees. Once a proposal is received: the Regional Branch screens it to assess
 20 whether it falls within the ECD)F mandate; reflects the needs and priorities of the community and its commitment to sustain the facility financed by ECDF; is presented in a complete enough form; and appears feasible and sound in terms of technical details, cost and likely benefits, and implementability. Each proposal is recorded in the ECDF MIS system, and those positively screened are submitted to the Regional Branch for clearance to appraise. The appraisal, which includes a field visit, assesses the acceptability of the proposal on the basis of the sub-project's location, its sector/sub- sector, its likely benefits to beneficiaries, and the commitment of the relevant sectoral ministry or community group to cover recurrent costs associated with the sub-project. During the field visit, the Project Officer gives special attention to the broader impact of the sub-project on the community and special groups within the community (especially poor women); the likely returns on investment; factors determining both effective utilization and sustainability; the extent to which the project satisfies technical standards for the sector and is sensitive to environmental goals; the realism of project costings; the arrangements for implementation and supervision; and the commitment of beneficiaries to maintenance. A crucial factor is the cornmunity's own investment, which will be at least 10 percent of the project costs, in the form of cash, materials, labor or other services. In exceptional cases, the ECDF will agree that particularly poor communities be allowed to contribute to the sub-projects' costs with less than 10 percent. Social and Economic Infrastructure and Services 3.20 The ECDF will operate within the framework of overall national development priorities, and will not preclude any specific sector from consideration.  22 3.21 Social Sector Infrastructure and Services. In the social sectors, ECDF support would help communities willing to invest to increase their access to basic health and education, and would assist communities to increase the efficiency of basic social services delivery (including the utilization of facilities provided through ECRF financing). This should help to maximize the return on both public as well as private investments by the communities themselves, and encourage a shift to greater community participation and accountability. Social sector infrastructure projects would aim to integrate with relevant aspects of other sector sub-projects, such as rural water supply and sanitation, with health and education. 3.22 Primary Health. The rehabilitation, expansion, and construction of primary health care facilities (health stations and health centers) in areas where these facilities are unavailable, would be a core part of this aspect of ECDF support. The provision of this infrastructure would be carefully coordinated with the Ministry of Health and their local offices, and would be based on Government standards and regulations for these facilities. Annex J provides details of these standards, and of the cost assumptions. In this way, there would be a direct link between the provision of infrastructure, and the services and maintenance necessary for these to operate. Recurrent costs would be shared by the Government and local communities. The Ministry and regional administrations would be responsible for the training and salaries of health workers, and the provision of essential supplies; the ECDF, as agreed with the Ministry of Health would provide furniture and refrigeration equipment, wherever possible making purchases of these supplies on the local market where these are reasonably priced. The communities would make a wide variety of in-kind contributions related to the maintenance of the facilities, and their everyday operation. In addition, the Government is designing a system of cost-recovery through user charges that will be used to defray some portion of recurrent expenses currently borne by the Government budget. 3.23 The primary health component would emphasize health aspects of environmental sanitation and water supply. In addition, the construction of primary health infrastructure may be complemented by activities, such as training and the provision of improved local services, that can be managed on a community basis. These activities would respond to local needs, such as improvements in family health and nutrition practices, family planning, improved sanitation, and pre and post-natal health counseling. In all of these activities, the ECDF would work closely with local health officials to complement and assist, and not duplicate health programs planned or in operation. These training and services activities will pay special attention to women beneficiaries, and other groups in special need, such as the disabled and aged. An important aspect of ECDF activity would be the piloting of labor-saving methods to help alleviate the burden of women's work to encourage attention to health and nutrition problems. 3.24 Basic Education. ECDF's activities in this sector would include the rehabilitation, expansion, or construction, and equipping of primary schools, and junior secondary schools in areas where communities lack, request and are willing to invest in these basic facilities. All schools would be provided according to Government standards, and efforts would be made to adopt a flexible approach, providing smaller schools to
 23 isolated communities that are far away from larger village clusters. Annex J provides details of the Government standards and the costing of this component. Recurrent costs associated with the maintenance of the facilities and the provision of educational services, as well as of other types of sub-projects are dealt with in the following section. The responsibility for recurrent costs would be shared by the Government, and local communities. The division of responsibility is likely to evolve over time as the Government prepares a detailed sector investment plan and implements cost recovery mechanisms. Currently, the general policy is that the Ministry of Education covers the cost of teacher training and salaries, and because of shortages, textbooks are lent to pupils (who often have to share them) and recovered for subsequent use. Communities customarily make contributions in the form of maintenance of facilities, provision of services (such as food), in some cases housing for teachers, and other forms of participation in the running of the schools. However, there are areas where communities have been contributing to teacher salaries, and one or two provinces have already been experimenting with school fees and sale of textbooks. 3.25 As in the case of primary health facilities, the ECDF would work closely with the responsible Ministry (of Education) and its local representatives, guided by Government construction standards. The ECDF would encourage community participation in basic education management through parents' committees, and support efforts to improve the educational participation and performance of girls. The ECDF would also support community efforts to make the school facility a center for other community activities, such as basic skills training and pre-school child care centers. 3.26 Rural Water Supply. The water supply component would improve access to safe drinking water in under-served areas by supporting projects which rehabilitate and/or augment existing supplies, and develop new sources. All requests for new projects would therefore be reviewed to determine whether or not the rehabilitation of an existing source is a viable alternative. Rehabilitation would focus on protecting existing sources, improving access to safe water by repairing, fitting or replacing failed equipment (e.g. handpumps), and building distribution networks from existing point sources for large communities. The development of new sources would be focused on three schemes typologies: hand dug wells, bore holes, and piped water systems to allow ECDF to accommodate requests from communities of different sizes (250 - 8,000 persons) and characteristics (nomadic and sedentary). On an exceptional basis, and only where none of these alternative is technically feasible, other alternatives would be considered. 3.27 To the extent possible, drinking water supply sub-projects would be integrated with health and education sub-projects. All health and education sub-projects would include water and sanitation facilities. Drinking water supply sub-projects would also take into consideration other economic water supply requirements - such as livestock watering and kitchen gardening, and, where possible, these will be provided for. The practice of collecting user charges for both drinking water supply and livestock watering is already established in some parts of Eritrea, and the project would support and build on this.
 24 3.28 Beneficiary communities would be fully responsible for the operation and maintenance (recurrent costs) of their water supplies. This is a requirement of the ECDF, and an agreement between the Fund and the community would be drawn up to reflect this commitment. ECDF would discuss alternative technologies with communities to ensure that they are aware of the operation and maintenance requirements and recurrent costs implications of the schemes they select. ECDF would also assist the communities to establish appropriate user charges, and establish sound financial practices. 3.29 A key element for the success of this component is capacity building support for communities. This would help to ensure that communities not only participate in identification of sub-projects, but also have the required skills to operate, maintain and manage their water supply in the long term. Technical capacity within the Government would also need to be strengthened to facilitate technical assistance, training, and the implementation of community awareness creation programs. Efforts would be made to ensure that gender concerns are adequately addressed by the capacity building program. Private sector capacity would be strengthened through a series of seminars and courses. 3.30 Feeder Road Rehabilitation. The overall aim of this component is to assist the Government to improve access to and from rural communities, markets and social services. The proposed improvements will contribute to meet the local transport needs of rural communities (including within village needs). The proposed activities would include: (i) survey and design of feeder roads, bridges and river crossings; (ii) rehabilitation and spot improvements of up to 1270 km of feeder roads; (iii) construction of small bridges, culverts and fords or river crossings (an estimated 1 10 box culverts, and 120 ford or river crossings); (iv) construction of retaining walls and other types of environmental protection measures for all types of RRT (Rural Road Transport) improvements; (v) strengthening of ECDF Management Office and Regional Branches, and of regional administrations through recruitment and training of staff for programming, survey and design of feeder roads, and supervision of works; and, (vi) training for representatives from beneficiary communities to use guidelines and systems to plan, manage, maintain, and make proper use of RRT improvements. 3.31 The ECDF would provide support to the following types of rural road transport improvements: (i) seasonal vehicular access tracks (through spot improvements), e.g. for agricultural purposes; (ii) local all-weather vehicular access roads and tracks (including within villages roads, and associated drainage and safety measures), which may or may not meet rural roads standards; (iii) rural roads of district significance (e.g., major rural roads serving groups of communities and important district/woreda administrative centers); (iv) a few selected rural roads of regional significance (roads which are links in the regional rural road networks); (v) environmentally sound and safe community footpaths and pack animal trails; and, (vi) low-cost tracks for appropriate intermediate means of transport (IMTs), such as animal-drawn carts, hand carts, and bicycle-based transporters. In addition, the ECDF's support to the creation of local micro-credit institutions would make resources available for the introduction of IMTs, and local transport services. The support would go to entrepreneurs wishing to engage in the local manufacture, marketing and operation of affordable IMTs and other local transport.

The Unit therefore provides a main nucleus for feeder roads program coordination in association with the Planning Department of the Ministry.
