An engineer will be assigned full time to manage the program within the ECDF Management Office. The ECDF will then assist in establishing the engineering capacity in the regional administrations for the supervision and management of future feeder road rehabilitation and maintenance programs 3.33 Surveys and design of all the roads and structures would be carried out in the first two years of activity. Some road rehabilitation, culvert and river construction would start in the first year. The project team would review the annual program of roadworks at the end of each year to establish the scope of works for the next financial year. Ad hoc cost recovery arrangements are already on-going in some regions, including the charging of tolls for the use of the roads, and they provide experiences to build upon in ECDF financed projects. 3.34 Soil, Water and Forestry Conservation. ECDF would adopt an integrated approach to soil, water and forestry conservation, in line with the on-going Government policy. This extended menu of options would include hillside closure and natural revegetation, the construction of simple stone or soil bunds, planting of grass strips (e.g. with vetiver glass) along the contour, trash lines, retention of crop residues to improve ground cover, retention of dung to enhance fertility, minimum tillage, etc. Similarly, the frequent prescription of eucalyptus planting to combat deforestation would be enriched with the provision of indigenous species, fruit trees which can play an important nutritional role, and generally receive a high level of protection by villagers, fodder trees that can enhance livestock feeding, and leguminous trees. 2. Pilot Savings and Credit Program 3.35 Objective. The Project will also support the launching of a pilot Savings and Credit (S&C) program aimed at supporting investment in economic activities at the village (or town) level. The program's objective will be to demonstrate the effectiveness of institution-building efforts aimed at creating new income and employment opportunities in targeted communities, and at contributing to the improvement of living standards and to increased overall prosperity of these communities. 3.36 Approach and Methodology. This objective will be pursued through the provision of savings and credit services to substantial numbers of Eritreans in pilot areas. Credit will be provided incrementally to individuals who have first demonstrated a minimum capacity to save for at least three months. These individuals will then become eligible for credit to finance various economic activities in the community. However, they will be asked to get together into groups that will operate according to the solidarity group concept which has proven successful in other programs around the world (each group member is responsible for the repayment of loans extended to other members of the
 26 group--all group members will be denied access to further credit until all loans to group members have been repaid). These groups will then be supported and supervised by village-level community-based organizations, as described below (see Annex M for a detailed description of the basic village banking model adopted by the program). 3.37 Group members will be eligible, subject to approval of loan purpose by other group members and by the Baito S&C Sub-Committee responsible for program activities, to small loans initially of up to Birr 750 (approximately US $100) typically repayable over six months. The loan amounts could be increased to Birr 6,000 repayable over two years, depending on a successful repayment record. In order to take full opportunity of income-generating and employment-creation opportunities in program areas, the program will also fund a limited number of larger small enterprises either individually- or collectively-owned operating in these areas. These second-tier loans, which will range from Birr 10,000 to Birr 100,000, will require completion of a formal feasibility study and also require approval by ECDF's centrally-based S&C Unit. They will finance sub- projects providing benefits to the entire community (irrigation pumps, oil extraction presses, grain mills, food processing installation), or businesses able to generate employment at the community level (carpentry shops, tailoring operations). These loans will provide added flexibility to the S&C program, by filling gaps in availability of financing for larger somewhat more formalized ventures which would still have no access to commercial bank credit. 3.38 Management of Program at Village Level. The program will cover, during its first two years, three village clusters situated in separate regions of the country, to be extended to three additional clusters starting in Year 3. At first level of management, the program will rely on village Administrations or other institutions (selected on the basis of eligibility criteria included in the Operational Manual) that would offer adequate capacity to oversee the creation and operation of borrower groups and manage savings and credit activities--including savings deposits and withdrawals, and loan disbursements and collection.. For program purposes, village Administrations will establish three-person Savings and Credit (S&C) Sub-Committees (to include the village Administration Chairman) directly responsible for program implementation. At least one member of the Sub-Committee will be a woman.' 3.39 Regional-Level Management. ECDF will assign one S&C officer to each regional cluster during the first year of operation in that cluster, plus, as required, an S&C agent during the second year, as well as a second S&C agent during the third year. S&C officers and agents will be responsible for overall program activities in their region, working hand-in-hand with village Administration Sub-Committees to establish, train and supervise borrower groups. They will also closely monitor the administrative and financial functions performed by these Sub-Committees (particularly with respect to loan collection), while acting as liaison with head office. These field staff will play a critical role in preserving the program's operational and financial integrity, and will be subject to Other measures to ensure strong participation of women will include the taking into account of a field officer's success in reaching women as part of his/her evaluation criteria.
 27 strict performance evaluations based on expansion and performance of the program in their area (key evaluation criteria will include collection performance, as well as number of village banks created, number of new members, number of loans extended, and share of loans benefiting women). 3.40 Central-Level Management. The program will rely at the central level on a Savings and Credit Unit to be established within ECDF. The Unit will provide overall guidance for the program, carry out program-wide activities such as establishment of a management information system (the detailed outline of which was agreed upon during appraisal) and selection and training of field staff. It will also supervise and monitor field-based activities. The Government is fully aware of the importance of maintaining from the very start of the program the highest standards of administrative and financial performance, and of selecting a top-quality program manager to help enforce such standards. An overall program outline and a detailed operational manual were developed during project appraisal and agreed upon at that time with ECDF management. 3.41 Contribution to Financial Markets Development. Eritrea's financial system is still in its infancy. Although the country's National Bank is organizing itself to play some of the core functions of a central bank, Eritrea still uses the Ethiopian Birr as its currenicy, and, since it does not issue its own currency, has little control over its monetary policy. The state-owned Commercial Bank of Eritrea remains the only commercial bank in operation, reaching only a fraction of the country's population. Only a few scattered NGO-sponsored savings and credit programs are presently offering financial services to a few thousand amongst the vast majority of the population with little or no access to formal banking services. 3.42 In this context, the pilot S&C program can gradually contribute to the broadening of Eritrea's financial system. Although its initial outreach will be limited (270 rural and urban sites and 13,500 beneficiaries reached after Year 5), it will, if successful, constitute the basis for a viable institutional framework for the extension of savings and credit services to economic agents heretofore totally excluded from participation in formalized financial transactions. Also, the program will rely on an institutional mechanism (the Village Administration Sub-Committee) which offers strong potential for the establishment and growth of a community-based system oriented towards the rural- and urban-based micro-entrepreneur. Finally, the program will adopt a structure of interest rates fully consistent with long-term development of Eritrea's financial markets, sufficient to compensate for: (a) erosion of the fund through inflation; (b) cost of administration at the level of ECDF; and, (c) anticipated losses tied to bad debts. The village administrations or other FIs will on-lend to final beneficiaries at commercial rates. ECDF and IDA will review anmually the interest rate applied from ECDF to the financial intermediaries, and the plan for the next year of activity. 3. Capacity Building, Training, and Research 3.43 During the pilot phase, the Fund had limited resources for capacity building. Given the increased volume of activity in the expanded ECDF, the Project would include
 28 a practical and targeted training program designed to ensure effective implementation of Fund activities. Capacity building would help ensure that the Fund is appropriately decentralized, community based, and that the communities would play a primary role not only in the identification of sub-projects, but also in their implementation and monitoring, and the subsequent maintenance of facilities. Capacity building would target professional personnel in the Fund at the Central and Regional level; personnel in line ministries supporting Fund activities; facilitators assisting the ECDF in project promotion and implementation; and beneficiary communities and community leaders who would both have to contribute to the development of the project and utilize and maintain the assets built with ECDF financing. A promotion and Training Officer will be located in the MO to manage and coordinate all training and capacity building activities. 3.44 Capacity building activities for the expanded ECDF would be financed by a parallel program sponsored by a consortium of donors, which would start before the beginning of the expanded ECDF. The capacity building program would include among the activities necessary to prepare the expanded ECDF, the drawing up of a roster of national resources (government agencies, NGOs, individual consultants, or consulting firms) which can be used to provide the necessary training or technical assistance. The capacity building program would rely on Eritrean organizations and experts (selected through a process of competitive bidding), supplemented, where needed, by international specialists working under the supervision of ECDF. The approach would reflect the goal of strengthening local capacity, and emphasis would be given to training of trainers. Final agreement on the approach, content, and strategy for the capacity building programn has been reached at Appraisal, and is reflected in the Capacity Building Support Program document, available in the Project file. 3.45 The capacity building program would also include a research fund that would be used primarily to assess the real benefits of the ECDF from a community point-of view, and to ensure the necessary levels of quality in sub-project design and maintenance. 3.46 The pilot experience has identified some broad parameters and some specific areas to which the capacity building program would need to respond, although a needs analysis has been planned to identify the details of the program for the five year period of the Project. Three broad areas have been prioritized. Firstly, organizational strengthening and training activities would be provided to the management and professional personnel of the ECDF in the Management Office and Regional Branches. A second target for training would be the various facilitators assisting the ECDF and communities with sub- project design and implementation. These include local sector specialists and development officers located at regional and district level in the Reconstruction and Development Divisions (RDD) of Local Government. A third target would be community committees and beneficiary groups, with training focused on project design, implementation, and supervision, and the maintenance of infrastructure. 3.47 Approaches to Capacity Building. The capacity building component would give emphasis to team building, to enable the ECDF to accomplish its goals with a small number of staff and facilitators. Training methods would focus on group problem solving and group decision making, and strengthening the links among the ECDF Management
 29 Office and Regional Branches, local government, and the communities. The training would aim for a blend of building upon the realities of Eritrean conditions, and learning from the best of outside experience and specialized techniques. In areas of technical complexity, especially in the early years of the Project, training would be supplemented by technical assistance from experienced experts, who would provide a combination of training on-the-job, and consulting supervision at the actual construction sites. To widen the experience of ECDF staff, selective use would be made of out-of-country study tours and courses. 3.48 The program would support the identification and training of community facilitators that can maintain a link between the communities and ECDF. Training activities would be flexible and integrated and consist of a combinations of workshops, and seminars, on the job and on site support, formal training, and overseas courses and study tours. To strengthen its management approach training would be combined with organizational development methods. Capacity building at the community level, would make use of traditional village meetings and committee structures, supported by special workshops, the distribution of promotional materials, and use of mass media. 3.49 Capacity Building for the ECDF Staff Based on the pilot experience, the major capacity building priority for the ECDF itself will be the training of new project officers in the Fund's sub-project cycle: identification, preparation and appraisal, and implementation and supervision. At both Management Office and Regional Branches levels, the ECDF would strengthen its organizational capacity to handle the increased volume of activity the expanded program would generate, and to assist the gradual and incremental process of decentralization of responsibilities to Regional Branches. Specific measures include the use of a Monitoring and Information System (MIS), the use of strategic planning methods in developing the Fund's program, and a rigorous financial management and reporting system. Special training would also be required to support the program of promotion and community development. 3.50 Technical Assistance and Technical Training. Most of the capacity building efforts would focus on technical support for both Fund staff, facilitators, and local communities. This would involve both training activities, the development of a system of monitoring and physical inspection, and on site visitation by technical experts. Particular attention would be paid to the areas of water supply and rural road rehabilitation, where maintenance is a major responsibility of communities and local authorities. A complete set of training and capacity building activities has been designed to make possible the implementation of the pilot Savings and Credit component, and is included in the Capacity Building Support Document. 3.51 Capacity Building for Facilitators of Sub-Project Implementation. Local experts and administration officials would play an important role in supporting ECDF activities, by helping ensure that ECDF sub-projects meet sectoral standards, by providing technical support in design and supervision, and by assisting the ECDF staff in promotion and community development activities. Where needed, the capacity building component would train these facilitators in the Fund's procedures and processes, and in the management of community-based projects. Special tailor-made programs would also
 30 be organized for district and regional officials in sector-specific aspects of ECDF financed activities. 3.52 Capacity Building at the Community Level. The overall goal of the capacity- building program at the community level, is to assist communities to take the lead in utilizing the opportunities offered by the ECDF, through a realistic blend of strengthened self-reliance, and the ability to assess the need for expertise to be contracted outside. The first level of capacity building for communities would focus on training community beneficiaries in the approaches and procedures of the Fund, methods of identifying sub- projects of benefit to the community, methods of monitoring implementation progress and evaluating outcomes, and the skills to ensure effective community maintenance of assets. The second level would be training for community leaders and community project committees in managing the community's interests in the project cycle, including negotiating with Fund staff and facilitators, and contracting implementation services. Training would also cover basic skills in managing finances and supervising work in progress. The third level would be specialized programs that cover a particular theme (such as environmental conservation, the needs of poor women or other special groups, the use of community labor, the essential linkages among sectoral activities); or provide a specialized skill (for example, training in the use of a particular type of technology or equipment). The Bank's strategy, in line with the Government's policy, has a major target the alleviation of poverty. The results of the analytical activities carried out define four major sets of activities to achieve these objectives: (i) supporting the participation of communities in the development process, including the provision, management, and maintenance of basic social services, and building community managerial and implementation capacity; (ii) strengthening the role of private sector in local development efforts; (iii) improving cost-efficiency and maximizing cost-recovery in the provision of services; and (iv) focusing on the social and economic advancement of women, and on environmental conservation. The ECDF would provide an important vehicle to implement this strategy. 3.109 Moreover, the Bank has supported social funds in almost every region of the world. Like the pilot ECRF they have shown that community-initiated infrastructure projects can be implemented at a lower cost than equivalent publicly managed projects (see section on experience of the pilot ECRF). The social fund mechanism can be an effective way of attracting community investments for development, which reduces the costs to public funds and establishes a basis of ownership around which maintenance arrangements can be built. Successful social funds have made a valuable contribution to community development, by building managerial competencies, encouraging community decision making on shared assets, and developing a sense of achievement and self- reliance.
 46 Q. BENEFITS AND RISKS 3.110 Benefits. The ECDF will contribute to the much needed rebuilding of social and physical infrastructure in Eritrea. Since it is a demand-based project and will finance only those sub-projects that are requested by the communities, it is not possible to predict in advance the composition of the project. However, based on data gathered from the pilot phase, the following results are expected. It is expected that 22 primary and junior secondary schools will be built per year, increasing their total number from 575 now to 687 by the end of the decade. Based on the current norm of about 500 students per school, the new schools would provide enrollment opportunities for about 55,000 additional students, or an increase of over 20%. These schools would be built in villages and communities which do not have any facility at all, and it expected that they would be fully utilized since communities will have asked for them. There is not enough data yet in Eritrea to calculate the rate of return to this investment, but estimates for other countries show an average private rate of return of 41% to basic education in sub-Saharan Africa (higher than in any other part of the world) and a social rate of return of 24%. Additionally, there are other social benefits through the impact of education on health and fertility. It is also expected that about 20 health stations/centers will be built per year, increasing by two/thirds the number currently existing (160). Data on outpatient visits nationwide show that about 15,000 visits occur per year per health facility, translating to an average of less than one visit per person. This is exceptionally low; in other Sub- Saharan countries the number of visits is 1.5-2, and in more affluent countries it is 7-8. it is reasonably expected that with the project the utilization rate will increase closer to the regional average, with current improvement in health status. The ECDF would provide drinking water facilities to 230 communities covering 5% of the rural population. While there is no data on the availability of safe water in rural areas, it is known that most Eritreans have access only to unprotected wells and rivers. A study of 244 villages estimated that per capita consumption of clean water was only 2.5 liters per capita per day. For this meager amount women and children may travel up to 2 hours each way, contributing substantially to a long working day lasting 14-16 hours. School-age children, particularly girls may be held back from school (a study of distance to water facilities and school attendance in Nigeria has shown a strong correlation). The health consequences of polluted water are well-known; for example the percentage of deaths of children under five in Eritrea due to diarrhea is as high as 13% (double the rate in Uganda and Tanzania), and diarrhea is one of the leading causes of death for this group. 3.1 11 The project is also expected to rehabilitate and improve about 1,200 km of rural roads (about 50% of the feeder/local/minor roads network). In a country where nearly 100% of these roads are classified to be in poor or very poor condition, this component can be expected to provide a major impetus to increased economic activity, as well as better access to the social infrastructure being built. The micro-credit component will be tested on a pilot basis. Preliminary analysis of data on poverty collected in a Rapid Appraisal Survey (1993-94) shows that self-employment and trade is critical for growing out of poverty. The share of income from these activities, generally in the informal sector, is 21% for the non-poor, compared to about 10.5 for the poor. Experience elsewhere suggests that the provision of small amounts of capital can make a substantial
 47 difference. Experience with the pilot project demonstrates and enhances the cost- effectiveness and feasibility of realizing these benefits. 3.1 12 Risks. A mid-term evaluation of the Pilot Community Rehabilitation Fund was carried out in September 1994 by a team composed by local and international independent consultants, and its finding were discussed with the Government during a supervision mission carried out in February 1995. The objectives of the evaluation were to (i) assess the quality of sub-projects implementation and community participation; (ii) analyze the balance of ECRF's project portfolio; (iii) determine the relevance of ECRF-financed sub-projects to community needs; (iv) assess the management of sub-project operations; and (v) assess the scope for an expansion of ECRF activities, including the identification of capacity building needs. ECRF's overall performance was assessed as satisfactory, especially given the uncertainties due to the country situation in the immediate aftermath of the war, and the severe constraints (in terms of staffing and equipment) under which the Fund had to operate during its initial stage of operations. The evaluation identified the ECRF's greatest asset as its dedicated staff and their problem solving capacity and determination to succeed against substantial obstacles. At a greater level of specificity, the evaluation judged the most important achievements of the ECRF to be: (i) its outreach capacity to communities, specially in remote areas; and (ii) the quality and cost-effectiveness of the sub-projects implemented. 2. Content of the Evaluation. The evaluation focused on the following areas: (i) characteristics and structure of the ECRF; (ii) the project cycle; (iii) community participation and contribution; (iv) major achievements of ECRF; and (v) recommendations for an expanded phase. Section (i); (ii); and (iii) have been summarized in the main SAR. Section (iv) is summarized in the following paragraphs. 3. Recommendations for an Expanded Phase. The evaluation made recommendations concerning four major areas relating to: (i) capacity building, staff training and recruitment; (ii) expansion of ECRF activities; (iii) ECRF operations; and (iv) social infrastructure projects. Regarding capacity building, staff training, and recruitment the evaluation suggested that ECRF: (a) strengthen its outreach capacity through training for ECRF staff, (b) develop an improved salary scale and system of incentives to retain experienced staff, and attract the new staff necessary for the expanded phase; and (c) consider a phased program of decentralized responsibility to ECRF Sub- Units in the provinces, to improve the efficiency and responsiveness of ECRF's services to the communities. 4.  Annex I Page I of 6 Environmental Analysis I. Background. The purpose of this analysis is to assess whether: (i) the activities to be implemented under the project can be undertaken in a sound and sustainable manner; (ii) what scope there is to mitigate or minimize any potentially negative impacts or to promote environmentally positive actions; and (iii) whether the overall policy and institutional context as well as the technical capacity of the project staff are adequate for the purpose of ensuring that environmental issues can be given due weight and treated effectively during Project implementation. 2. The Policy Context: the National Environmental Management Plan for Eritrea (NEMP-E). In Eritrea, environmental issues have been assigned a high priority by the Government. This stems from a recognition that the sustainable use of the country's natural capital will be essential if the country's overall strategy for long-term growth is to be realized. This commitment, endorsed at the highest level of government, provides the backdrop to all major development programs being initiated and implemented in Eritrea and supplies an important impetus for the incorporation of environmental objectives into the activities of the ECDF. 3. In terms of the impact on income, productivity and human welfare, land degradation and the associated problem of deforestation are two areas of great concern in Eritrea. The other broad area of concern is the scarcity and poor quality of water resources. In the rural areas, year round access to drinking water is problematic while bacteriological contamination of water contributes to high morbidity rates among children. Lack of reliable water supply also affects agricultural and livestock productivity. The poor in Eritrea are the most vulnerable in situations of environmental degradation given their extensive reliance on the natural resource base around them. Consultations with communities during the preparation of the Government's National Environmental Management Plan for Eritrea (NEMP-E) revealed an acute awareness on the part of communities of the declining quality of their environment, yet little leeway to effectively address the problems. Lack of financial resources, limited knowledge of viable solutions or alternatives to harmful practices, and short-term planning horizons by farmers and households have all contributed to the perpetuation of environmental problems. 4. The Government of Eritrea has recently adopted a National Environmental Management Plan for Eritrea (NEMP-E). This document, which has been the result of a process of extensive consultation with and between both community organizations and all major ministries of the Government, was presented for review, comment and discussion at a National Conference on the Environment in February 1995. The main objective of the NEMP-E is to provide a framework for coordinating the protection and enhancement of Eritrea's natural resource base so that optimal social and economic development can be achieved. To this end the plan examines the interconnections between population, resources and environment within the Eritrean context, the relationship between NEMP-E and other national initiatives such as development planning and macroeconomic policies, and lays out a number of guiding principles for the integration of environmental objectives into the national planning process. The plan also highlights the main areas of environmental concern in the country. These cover issues relating to environmental health, natural resource management, including land, water, forests and the preservation of coastal areas and bio-diversity, and transboundary environmental issues. The plan also outlines the recommended institutional arrangements necessary to implement the plan and includes a compilation of programs and projects to support the objectives of the NEMP-E.
 Annex I Page 2 of 6 5. Implementation of the NEMP-E. The NEMP-E must be considered a starting point for the development of programs of action to address specific environmental issues and to lay the basis for evolving environmental standards and regulation. The real challenge now facing the country is to put the vision of the NEMP-E in practice. While the overall political will is high at the central level, implementation capacity remains weak and it could be several years before effective mechanisms are developed to enable the integration of environmental concerns into the mainstream development processes of the country. Institutional arrangements are yet to be finalized and recommended structures will take time to establish on a fornal basis. Most legislation relating to different aspects of resource management and environmental standards is at a very preliminary stage of development. The exception is the recent 'Land Proclamation' which effectively replaces all preceding forms of land tenure in the country with lifetimes usufruct rights to land. The proposed land reforns are initially to be implemented on a pilot basis and nationwide adoption will happen at a later date. Meanwhile there is a lack of information on the natural resource base, essential for sound environmental planning and management. 6. Although the general institutional and legislative context for environmental management in which the ECDF would operate will be sketchy, there is nevertheless scope for ensuring that the Project can pursue the environmental objectives outlined in the NEMP-E. First, there would be a concerted effort to develop ECDF's own capacity for environmental assessment and monitoring. Indeed one of the underlying themes of the NEMP-E is that the environment should be treated not as a separate sector requiring specialist inputs, but as an integral component of all sectors. The Eritrean Agency for the Environment (EAE), established as an interim secretariat within the Ministry of Local Government, but with a high degree of autonomy, will act as catalyst and coordinator of environmental activities in the country with corresponding environmental councils to be located at the regional level. It will also work at building up the skills and awareness of existing Government staff in the line ministries and strengthening the capacity of individual ministries to oversee the implementation of environmental assessments for projects within their respective areas of responsibility. 7. Second, through its close working associations with other Government departments, it is expected that the Project would be able to benefit from on-going efforts at building up and strengthening the data and information base on natural resources, particularly in the Ministry of Agriculture and the Department of Water Resources. 8. Third, with its close working relationship with community groups and organizations, it is envisaged that ECDF could make a considerable impact on environmental issues by interacting directly at the local level. In fact, the NEMP-E envisages that better environmental practices can be encouraged through a collaborative partnership between communities and the government, based on an ongoing dialogue that would respect the traditional knowledge of communities while in turn raising public awareness and supporting communities in finding more sustainable ways of interacting with their environment. This is a process that need not depend on the existence of formal government mechanisms for implementation. Instead it is expected to rely on the traditionally strong organizational and mediating capacities of local village baitos to educate, mobilize and enforce local level regulations in pursuit of environmental objectives. 9. Environmental Issues Relating to Sub-Projects. Any program of poverty alleviation such as the ECDF, and particularly if targeted at the rural areas, will inevitably entail activities which impinge in some way on the local natural resource base. In a country such as Eritrea, where a high degree of economic vulnerability prevails, a major concern is to ensure that efforts at alleviating poverty should not result in the degradation of the natural resource base or in
 Annex I Page 3 of 6 environmental health hazards that exacerbate this vulnerability. The objective of the Government of Eritrea under the ECDF is to achieve a fine balance between encouraging the productive use of the natural resource base and ensuring the protection and conservation of these same resources. In most cases the negative environmental impact of the individual micro-project to be funded under the ECDF is expected to be localized and limited. However, a number of environmental issues can be highlighted under each sub-sector as follows: 10. Water Supply. Water supply projects under the ECDF could generally be expected to yield positive environmental outcomes for the communities concerned. Two main issues deserve attention: (i) Use of water points for watering livestock. In the lowland areas in particular, there may be the risk of increased livestock concentrations around new water points with adverse effects on surrounding grazing land. However, it is anticipated that most of the requests for water points would emanate from sedentary farming communities who would be expected to assume responsibility for regulating the use of such water points primarily for domestic consumption. (ii) Contamination of water source through poor maintenance of the wvater point surroundings. The risk of such contamination can generally be offset by proper design of the water point and training of community members in appropriate maintenance practices. 11. Road Construction, As the road-works envisaged under this project would consist mostly of the upgrading of existing footpaths and rehabilitation of existing small-scale feeder roads, the adverse environmental impact is not anticipated to be significant. The following points may need particular consideration, however: (i) Erosion and slope stability. Local erosion problems can be exacerbated and slope stability disturbed by road construction. These can be the result of deficient drainage or modification of water flows. In most instances, potential problems can be avoided or mitigated through appropriate design or by taking measures such as the prompt replanting of vegetation on road embankments. (ii) Impact on the local water system. Construction of a road could contribute to changes in the flow and quality of surface water and groundwater, sometimes resulting in increased flooding, siltation, or drying up of natural groundwater reserves/supplies. Most of the roads envisaged under the ECDF are likely to be too small to have any major impact on water flows. 12. Social Infrastructure Projects. The environmental impact of these structures is likely to be minimal. The only potential area of concern, would be to ensure the safe disposal of hazardous materials from health centers. This can be achieved through the separation of degradable and non- degradable materials and the construction of protected disposal pits for the more hazardous materials. Meanwhile there would be scope to encourage environmentally positive measures under this category of sub-projects. For instance the construction of pit latrines that can also serve as demonstration sites could have a positive impact on hygiene practices, particularly amongst school children, while the inclusion of properly designed roof catchments could help to improve the availability of water. 13. Pilot Savings and Credit Program. The Government anticipates that a wide range of micro-enterprise and income-generating proposals would be received. Given the small-scale of the activities envisaged, relatively few are expected to raise issues of any real consequence to the

Typically the proposals are expected to include such activities as bee-keeping, garnent making, establishing of grinding mills, etc., all of which are reasonably benign activities as far as their impact on the environment is concerned. Obvious exception would be proposals involving intensive use of raw materials such as wood for fuel or construction (e.g. brick-making kilns), or activities generating potentially hazardous wastes (e.g. metal works, or skin and hides production). Such proposals would be specifically reviewed with the community concerned in order to find appropriate alternative materials or solutions for waste management. 14. Soil, Water, and Forestry Conservation.. The government is also envisaging the implementation of a number of "natural resources management" projects. These projects would generally consist of hillside terracing, tree-planting and construction of check dams in catchment areas or on road embankments. While these kinds of activity are aimed at environmental improvements, a number of points will need to be kept in mind: (i) Terracing. The beneficial effects of terracing are likely to be increased water infiltration and hence recharging of local aquifers, as well as increased agriculture productivity. However, in some catcliment areas, given low rainfall levels and high evapo-transpiration rates, extensive terracing can also have the effect of reducing the amount of water that drains into the catchment ar;a. It would thus be important at the design stage of the project to obtain at least a basic picture of the main hydrological characteristics of the catchment area so as to give a reasonably informed estimate of the extent of terracing required to yield positive environmental effects. It would be also important to assess whether any productivity and hydrological benefit can be achieved. (ii) Tree planting. Tree planting has been widely encouraged in Eritrea because of the acute shortage of wood and tree products in most areas of the country. It is also thought to have the added benefit of helping to stabilize slopes and reducing surface run-off and soil loss. Some of these benefits can be expected to accrue under the present project. However, attention will need to be paid to the siting of tree plantation and to the kind of species promoted. Given low rainfall and high evapo-transpiration rates, tree planting, in some locations, may have the unintended effect of reducing groundwater availability and of depriving surrounding vegetation of moisture. The effect can be particularly serious if fast growing but water-hungry species such as eucalyptus are planted in areas which are already water scarce. It would be important for the Project staff to have a sound understanding of the local ecology of areas to be planted and to ensure that appropriate species are used if planting is to proceed. Enforced enclosures that encourage the regeneration of natural vegetation on hillsides imnay often be a more effective form of environmental conservation than tree plantations. (iii) Ensuring maintenance of terrace.: A problem reported by many agencies that have sponsored large-scale terracing programs in Eritrea, is that of maintenance of the structures once in place. The problem has often been that community members do not see any direct benefit to themselves in undertaking such work and are hence reluctant to devote time to maintenance unless compensated by food or cash. Poor maintenance of terraces can sometimes cause greater problems than they were originally designed to address as the collapse of any one part of a terrace can lead to the formation of deep gullies that only exacerbate soil loss and run-off. The ECDF would experiment various community approaches and incentive measures to ensure the long-term commitment of communities to the maintenance of terraces or, where appropriate, tree plantations. For example, one approach would be to introduce low-cost measures such as grass-strips, using vetiver grass, soil and stone bunds, and encouraging retention of dung and crop residues on cropland to improve ground cover, enhance soil fertility, and ultimately improve yield. The low-cost
 Annex I Page 5 of 6 provision of fuelwood as an energy alternative to dung, fuel saving stoves, and improved cut-and carry fodder as a substitute for crop residues are important elements of this strategy. 15. There are an estimated 247,000 people working in informal sector activities in Eritreat, many of which belong to the 80% of households that are involved in small- scale agriculture. These micro-entrepreneurs lack access to the needed resources to invest in their enterprises. To assess their needs, the Income Generating Committee set up within the pilot Community Rehabilitation Fund completed a comprehensive nation-wide survey of income- generating activities, using a questionnaire at the household, community, district, and zonal levels. A separate study was undertaken of Ekubs, a traditional, informal village savings mechanism found mainly in the highlands and which operates similarly to the group-based lending system proposed in the program. The study indicates that while the major source of livelihood in the interior is tied to agriculture and pastoralism, a large number of agriculture- related and off-farm economic activities were identified in each region. 2. Objectives and Priorities. The goal of ECDF's pilot Savings and Credit Program will be to demonstrate the effectiveness of institution-building efforts aimed at creating new income and employment in poor communities and at contributing to the improvement of living standards and to increased overall prosperity of these communities. This goal will be achieved through: (a) Developing the capacity of Village Administrations to manage a village-based Savings and Credit Program that will deliver needed financial services to target beneficiaries. (b) Developing the capacity of ECDF to manage a large-scale, cost-effective, financially rigorous micro-credit program. (c) Providing credit to the income-generating activities of substantial numbers of Eritreans. (d) Reaching women, the poor, and those living in isolated towns and villages, making use of both their entrepreneurial capacity and their sense of responsibility. (e) Creating the basis for a permanent, self-sustaining Savings and Credit institution that will serve an expanding number of communities after the completion of the ECDF program. 3. The Program Model. One of the most interesting innovations of the last two decades has been the emergence of programs that have assisted the informal businesses of some of the poorest residents of a country, by the thousands, hundreds of thousands, and even millions (in the case of the Grameen Bank), while covering most of their operating costs through the interest and fees charged on loans. These programs are based on the creation of autonomously functioning "village banks," typically with 30 to 50 members. The "banks", which elect their own officers, create their bylaws, manage their loan funds, and review and approve loan requests, have proved to be virtually the only types of business assistance programs that: (a) Reached truly substantial numbers of the rural and urban poor, especially women. Loans are uncollateralized and do not require co-signers, or land titles or other securities, which insures that the poor participate. 1 A report prepared by the Ministry of Trade and Industry in May, 1995 estimates that these 247,000 people working as owners and employees support 1. 1 million people. (c) Produced impressive results in terms of generating new income, which then translated into improved nutrition and better housing, education and health care, especially when assistance was directed to women. (d) Proved to be an excellent organizational platform for introducing simple notions of business literacy, and other services such as basic health education for women, where the messages are reinforced by the cohesive structure that emerges in the group. (e) Encouraged the formation of village-run collective businesses, such as grain storage facilities, financed by the savings and interest income mobilized from the members. (h) Proved they can pay for the costs of the intermediary promoting the program within a few years, if an adequate interest charge is paid on capital made available by the intermediary. (i) Have proved to be a powerful tool to free the poorest from the high interest rates charged by money lenders. 4. Village Banking and the Baitos. Applying lessons learnt from the above models, it is proposed that the pilot Savings and Credit Program operate through Village Administration Committees or other institution such as NGOs and community development institutions which may in the future offer an established capacity to implement program activities. The Village Administration Committees are democratically elected and, although there are doubtless great variations in capacity, have been found to share a common concern for the development of the community, and especially of its more disadvantaged members. It is proposed that the program be administered at the village level through a Savings and Credit Unit established by the Village Administration and consisting of three members, including: the Village Administration Chairperson, a manager responsible for accounts and record keeping, and one other member. At least one of the three Unit members will be a woman, in order to insure that women receive a representative share of available loan capital. The woman representative will be elected by all women in the village. 5. The Village Administration Unit will be responsible for: promoting the program within the community. They will also be responsible for: (a) orienting and supervising "solidarity groups" of five to eight borrowers within the village, who would band together to approve and guarantee each other's loans; (b) keeping records on savings and loan payments; and, (c) deal with payment problems. Each group would choose its own members and elect its officers. To insure that women receive credit early on in the program in each village, at least one of the initial groups would be comprised of women. A majority of the first cycle of loans would also go to poorer, yet entrepreneurial and responsible, community residents. Further access to credit for any member in the group would depend on all members being current with their loans. In addition to serving as a guarantee for the loans, the groups would promote mutual support and
 Annex M Page 3 of 7 encouragement as well as develop leadership and management skills. They would also foster joint marketing and production in the village. 6. If a group missed a payment, the Village Administration Unit would encourage the group to pay. If the group could not or would not pay, the Village Administration Unit would be liable for the payment, so ECDF could be paid in full. This requirement will ensure that the Village Administration Units take seriously their responsibility for prudently managing the program. The Unit would review the loan decisions of the groups, keep complete records on loan transactions and savings accounts, collect payments and savings from the groups, and deal with payment problems that the group couldn't resolve. The Unit would also be the link between the local groups and the ECDF Savings and Credit Officer. The Village Administration Unit would receive extensive training on program operation, including group formation and training, project assessment, and record keeping. This training would also include development by each Village Administration Unit of a set of bylaws. The bylaws would establish criteria for selecting village members to join the program, along with rules for approving loans, and the actions the Unit would take in case of late or non-payment. Solidarity group chairpersons and other community leaders would also receive training as the groups emerged. The ECDF Savings and Credit Officer would visit village programs on a monthly basis. In addition, the books of each Unit would be reviewed by a traveling ECDF auditor twice a year. 7. Lending and Savings Activities: Micro-loans. Group members would become eligible for loans after having successfully accumulated savings for a period of three months. Initial loans could amount to up to Birr 750 per borrowing group member, and would be repaid in 3 months. Subsequent loan amounts would be increased in steps to, possibly, a maximum of Birr 1,500, repayable in 6 months; Birr 3,000, repayable in up to one year, and Birr 6,000, repayable in up to two years. Receiving the next size loan would be contingent on the group paying the previous loans in full. 8. Second Tier Loans. While the major thrust of the program would be the micro-loans described above, a "second tier" of the program would finance larger (Birr 10,000 to 100,000) small business loans that would provide benefits to the entire community for the financing of, for example, irrigation pumps, oil extraction presses, grain mills, and small food processing installations, as well as other businesses able to generate new employment, such as carpentry shops, or tailoring operations. These second-tier loans will provide added flexibility to the S&C program by filling gaps in availability of financing for larger, somewhat more formalized ventures which would still have no access to commercial bank credit, because of the absence of formal banking sector in rural areas. These businesses could be owned individually or collectively, but, in contrast to the micro-loans that will be processed through the solidarity groups and the Unit, these projects would be only screened initially in the field by the Unit together with the regional S&C specialist. They would then be subject to a formal feasibility study by the ECDF Management Office, with the involvement of credit specialists from the commercial Bank of Eritrea. In order to ensure repayment, equipment and other assets would be pledged against the loan. Second-tier loans would be approved only after assessing the strength of the program in the applicant's village. To minimize the risk of default, only Village Administration Units that have demonstrated good management and repayment in the S&C program would be allowed to sponsor second-tier loans. 9. Interest Rates. The program's long-term financial sustainability can only be insured if borrowers are charged an interest rate which: (a) covers operational costs (including the cost of loan defaults); and (b) compensates for the Fund's erosion through inflation. ECDF will make
 Annex M Page 4 of 7 funds available to Village Administration Units and other institutions at an interest rate sufficient to cover the above. At the retail level, Village Administration Units will be free to determine the interest rate charged to individual borrowers. Such rate would in any case cover the true cost of lending to an economic group with no normal access to commercial credit and which does not fit lending conditions applied by formal lending institutions (absence of collateral, high cost of lending to very small, widely-dispersed borrowers).2 The above policies are fully consistent with policies and regulations applicable to the functioning of financial markets, as confirmed by the State Bank of Eritrea. 10. Those interested in borrowing would begin by saving through their group for at least six months, to demonstrate group solidarity and their commitment to the S&C Program. Potential borrowers would be required to save at least 10% of the loan amount before a loan was granted. Savers would receive a 5% interest on their deposits (which is competitive with the interest rate paid by the Commercial Bank of Eritrea on deposits). The savings of a borrower would be at risk in case of default, and would constitute a loan loss reserve on each loan for the Village Administration Unit. Those not borrowing would also be encouraged to save, in order to build up the local fund and thus lessen, through internally-generated savings, the need for external capital provided by ECDF through the loan fund. 11. Administration of the Program: Management Office Level. The Savings and Credit Central Unit will: (a) develop and perfect the program methodology; (b) be responsible for overall management of the loan fund; (c) hire, train and supervise the regional-level staff; (d) track program performance at the regional level; and, (e) give final approval of second-tier loans. The unit will also contract program advisors, undertake program evaluations, and manage the program overall. 12. Regional Level. ECDF will staff the program in each region with a Savings and Credit Specialist At the beginning of the second year, one Savings and Credit Agent would be hired, if necessary, to expand the program within the region. At the beginning of the third year, another Agent would be hired. Each Specialist and Agent will serve an average of 15 village banks with a total of 750 members. Their chief responsibilities will be to select the Village Administration Units that will participate in the program, train and supervise the village banks, and carefully monitor the entire program. The Savings and Credit Specialists will be responsible for supervising the agents, and making the initial assessment of the second-tier loans in the region. 13. Village banks will be ranked on a five-point scale each six months by the ECDF staff and by a roving auditor. This ranking will include such variables as the amount lent, the proportion of the loans that went to poor women and other poor and vulnerable groups, and loan repayment record. Communities that receive the highest rating during the six-month reviews will be permitted to expand their loan portfolios rapidly with additional advances from the ECDF Fund. Those that receive a very poor rating will be phased out of the program, while those with 2 The interest rate would be calculated on the basis of the following assumptions: (i) ECDF to village banks or other financial intermediaries: 12 percent (intended to cover an estimated inflation rate of 10 percent, plus a modest administrative fee of 2 percent); and (ii) Village Bank to final borrower: at a rate to be determined by the village bank, but sufficient to fully cover: (a) the cost of the funds (12 percent as above); (b) cost of administration of the loan portfolio (taking into account experience with similar programs worldwide); and (c) loan loss provision.
 Annex M Page 5 of 7 intermediate ratings will receive either a reduced advance from ECDF, or will see further advances suspended until internal management problems are resolved. Each month, Village Administration Units will be advanced funds to meet their projected cash needs, within the limits reflecting their rating. The amounts advanced will be determined during monthly visits to each Village Administration Unit by ECDF staff. Monthly advances will minimize the risk of storing large amounts of unlent cash in areas where banks are not available. 14. Program Implementation. The implemenitation projections below reflect an approach to expansion of this pilot program that avoids the dual pitfalls of a program growing too rapidly-- with the strong possibility of the program failing in some areas--, and a program growing so cautiously that little of the demand for loans is actually addressed. the following steps are foreseen: (a) Starting immediately after Negotiation, ECDF staff will receive intensive training in managemenit of the program. At the end of the formal training, detailed program procedures and manuals will be tested in select villages, preferably in one or two areas near Asmara. The program will only expand modestly in these areas until full project financing is available. (b) Once full funding is secured. the pilot program will begin in earnest in three village clusters for a two-year period, usin1g the S&C specialists. (c) By the middle of the first year of operations, an additional three regional managers will be hired. T hey will be assigned to a six-month apprenticeship in the areas where the program is already underway, so that they can fully familiarize tihemselves with the program before they are assigned to their own program areas. (d) By the start of the second year, and after the trainees have completed their four- month apprenticeship, they will be assigned to three new areas. This will bring the total of village clusters served to six. (e) In the second and again in the third year that a region has an operational program, a Savings and Credit Agent will be hired to expand the program in the area. Each region will thus have a team of three to promote the program, with each one responsible for traininig and supervising an average of 15 village banks. Agents may be hired from village Administration UJnits members who have demonstrated an exceptional level of capacity and commitment to the program. 15. Performance Projections. It will take four years. then, for the program to be fully staffed with Savings and Credit Specialists and S&C Agents in all six village clusters. The same go- slow, purposeful expansion approach will be reflected in the projected expansion of the program in a given cluster: (a) S&C activities will be concentrated in a fairly densely populated zone within each cluster, in order to minimize logistical problems. It may be necessary to station Specialists and Agents in different areas within a regioni to maximize coverage. (b) It is assumed that each Specialist or Agent will select, train and supervise five village banks, averaging 50 members each, during their first year of service. They will expand the number of village banks they work with to 15 by the end of their third year of service. 16. By the end of the fifth year of operation in a region, the team of one Specialists and two Agents would then be supporting and supervising 45 village banks with approximately 2,250 members. As the program expands to all six regions, the program would be reaching 270 village banks with 13,500 members. In addition to the grouip member loans, the program should have funded 90 Tier-2 loans by the end of the fifth year, an average of one per three village banks.

doc.abstracts: The Eritrea Community Development Fund Project (ECDF) will finance community-based sub-projects which in turn will: 1) support the rehabilitation and development of basic social and economic infrastructure critical to the improvement and development of the economic and social conditions of the population, especially in the remote and war devastated areas of Eritrea; and 2) improve the income-generating capacity of poor people and households. The sub-projects will include such social sector projects as the rehabilitation and construction of schools, health stations and clinics, water supply sources, and sanitation equipment. The sub-projects will be beneficial to the environmental conservation in areas affected by soil erosion and deforestation. The sub-projects will also provide communities with techniques for identifying development priorities, managing project implementation, and maintaining assets. The ECDF will not implement projects, but will support and facilitate the efforts of local communities and will ensure the provision of technical expertise in project implementation and management wherever the community needs. The implementation of the rehabilitation works will be carried out in a decentralized, pragmatic, and flexible way, and will give a large responsibility to the community for preparation and supervision.
